section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: In this hands‑on section learners will explore how to create and manipulate variables, work with Python's built‑in data types, and perform type conversions. Each lesson includes practical coding exercises that reinforce concepts through immediate application.
learning_objectives: Students will be able to declare variables using correct naming conventions and assign values of various data types.
Students will be able to identify, create, and manipulate primitive data types such as integers, floats, booleans, and strings.
Students will be able to construct, index, slice, and modify collection types including lists and tuples.
Students will be able to perform explicit type conversions, check data types at runtime, and handle conversion errors.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to declare variables following Python naming rules and assign values of different types using the assignment operator.
key_topics: Variable naming conventions and case sensitivity
Assignment operator (=) and multiple assignment
Dynamic typing and implicit type inference
Reassigning variables to new data types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a script that creates variables named age, price, is_student, and greeting. Assign them an integer, a float, a boolean, and a string respectively. Print each variable on a separate line.
Assign the values 10, 20, and 30 to variables x, y, and z in a single line of code. Then swap the values of x and y without using a temporary variable and print the result.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to identify and use Python's primitive data types: int, float, bool, and str, and perform basic type conversions.
key_topics: Integer literals and arithmetic operations
Floating‑point literals and precision considerations
Boolean literals (True, False) and logical expressions
String literals, concatenation, and formatting
Explicit conversion functions: int(), float(), str(), bool()

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables a, b, c, and d with the values 42, 3.14, True, and "Python". Use the type() function to print each variable's type.
Write a program that prompts the user for their birth year, converts the input to an integer, calculates their age assuming the current year is 2024, and prints the result.

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Collections: Lists and Tuples
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, index, slice, and modify lists and tuples, and understand the mutability differences between them.
key_topics: List literals and tuple literals syntax
Zero‑based indexing and negative indices
Slicing syntax start:stop:step
Mutability of lists vs. immutability of tuples
Common list methods: append(), insert(), remove(), pop(), sort(), reverse()
Tuple packing and unpacking

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a list called scores containing the numbers 88, 92, 79, 93. Append a new score of 85, replace the third element with 80, and then print the sorted list.
Define a tuple person = ("Alice", 30, "Engineer"). Unpack the tuple into variables name, age, and profession, then print a sentence using those variables.

lessons.lesson_title: Data Type Conversion and Type Checking
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert between data types safely, use isinstance() for runtime checks, and handle conversion errors with try/except.
key_topics: Explicit conversion functions: int(), float(), str(), bool()
Using type() to inspect an object's type
isinstance() for type verification
Error handling with try/except during conversion
Common conversion pitfalls (e.g., converting non‑numeric strings)

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a function safe_int(value) that attempts to convert value to an integer. If conversion fails, the function should return None without raising an exception. Test the function with inputs "123", "abc", and 45.6.
Prompt the user to enter a value. Use isinstance() to determine if the entered value (after conversion to float) is an integer (i.e., has no fractional part). Print "Integer" or "Float" accordingly.
